metadata.title: The flow of trade, urban development, and cultural symbolism
metadata.author: Tomas Hinrichs

caption.text: All the larger commercial ships could only be anchored up to half way up the Long Wharf, because the deep-harbor didn't make it all the way to land.
caption.title: Entry of trade

caption.text: Merchant's Row can be seen here as the street between the central King's Street and Faneuil Hall, the large building with a T next to it. The close proximity of Merchant's Row to Long Wharf allowed for the trading vessels to have fast and efficient unloading of goods to warehouses and stores. Slaves were also auctioned throughout this area and at Faneuil Hall.
caption.title: Merchant's Row

caption.text: The settlement of Boston was developed closely around the avenues of trade; Boston significantly depended on the Atlantic sea trading economy for its sustainability and growth..
caption.title: Gravitational pull of trade on patterns of habitation

caption.text: The Old State House, seen here at the top left of the image, to the right of the giant A, was where the centralized government of the Colony of Massachusetts existed. There was a bit of cultural symbolism operating here; from the second floor of the Old State House, the governor could easily see all the trade occurring at Merchants Row. The building was built to face towards England, so, in a straight line, the symbolism went like this: 1. Governor (Old State House) 2. Trade (Merchants Row) 3. Towards King and homeland (Long Wharf)
caption.title: Cultural symbolism with the Old State House
